EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Ohio Valley through the Mass Turnpike region of southern New England, bringing a prolonged period of freezing rain and sleet to southwest New Hampshire. This resulted in as much as one quarter to one half inch of icing, which caused widespread damage throughout Cheshire and Hillsborough Counties. There were many reports of downed trees, large branches, and power lines from Keene to Manchester. At the peak of the storm, around 38,000 homes were left without power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, large branches, and power lines were brought down by icing in Nashua, Hudson, and Manchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure center developed along the Mid-Atlantic coast and moved east of Nantucket, spreading snow across southwestern New Hampshire.  Storm snowfall totals ranged from six to eight inches.

Two low pressure systems merged into a storm over eastern Massachusetts and produced strong winds and heavy snow across New Hampshire.  One indirect fatality occurred when a car collided with a snow removal machine in Nashua.  The driver of the car died from injuries sustained in the crash.

A low pressure system that moved across northern New England and another low pressure system that formed south of Long Island merged along the southeast coast of Massachusetts. This storm produced heavy snow across much of southern New Hampshire.  An eight year old girl was seriously injured (indirect) while playing outside when she slipped and fell in front of a snowblower and got sucked into the machine.

High pressure across the St. Lawrence Valley locked in cold air across southern New England and combined with low pressure south of the coast to produce a significant snowfall.  Snow fell at rates of up to two inches per hour for an eight to ten hour period resulting in nearly a foot of snow in most locations.  Many motorists were affected as early dismissals from work and school just before snow began created rush hour like conditions which limited the snowplows' ability to plow.

Low pressure over the Carolinas strengthened as it tracked over southeast Massachusetts and Cape Cod Bay. This winter storm brought heavy snow and sleet to southwest New Hampshire, with totals of 8 to 15 inches on average.|The lower portion of Interstate 93 was littered with spinouts, rollovers, and cars off the road, but no serious injuries were reported. Accidents backed up traffic in both directions on the interstate.|Some specific snowfall totals, as reported by cooperative observers and trained spotters, included 15 inches in Francestown, 13 inches in Keene and Peterborough, 12 inches in Marlow, Merrimack and Milford, 10 inches in Walpole, Westmoreland, Winchester, Goffstown, and Hollis, and 9 inches in Swanzey, Troy, and Nashua.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 9 inches in Nashua to 12 inches in Merrimack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably chilly airmass moved into Southern New England behind a cold front on the 22nd of May. Several locations in Northern Massachusetts and Southwestern New Hampshire experienced a frost with low temperatures dropping into the lower to mid 30s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Early morning low temperatures were as follows: Greenville 34; Milford 38; Francestown 33; and Hudson 35.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed off the mid Atlantic coast and tracked through southeast Massachusetts. This storm brought a wintry mix of snow and sleet to southwest New Hampshire, with the highest snowfall totals in Hillsborough County where amounts averaged between 4 and 8 inches. |About 16,000 electric customers were left without power due to downed trees and wires from the weight of the snow At least six communities, including Manchester, set up shelters for people without heat or power. |Some specific snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 9 inches in Francestown and South Weare, 8 inches in Goffstown, 7 inches in Milford, and 5 inches in Nashua, Wilton, and Hudson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals averaged around 5 inches with significant impact from downed trees and wires, which caused widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure strengthened rapidly as it tracked from the mid Atlantic coast to Cape Cod. Snow began in southwest New Hampshire around midnight on the 14th, and mixed with sleet and freezing rain at times near the Massachusetts border during the day, before ending as flurries around midnight on the 15th. The combination of heavy snow, poor visibility, and snow covered roads led to dozens of minor accidents throughout Cheshire and Hillsborough Counties.|Snowfall totals averaged from as little as 6 to 10 inches in the Merrimack Valley to as much as 15 to 20 inches in northern sections of Cheshire and Hillsborough Counties. Some specific storm totals, as reported by trained spotters and cooperative observers, included 20 inches in Francestown, 17 inches in Nelson, 16 inches in Jaffrey and Swanzey, 14 inches in New Ipswich, 12 inches in Rindge and Greenfield, 10 inches in Hudson and Wilton, 8 inches in Bedford and Milford, and 6 inches in Mason and Nashua.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 6 inches in Nashua to 10 inches in Hudson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding across central and southern Yavapai County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of 6th and Cyprus Roads was flooded. A spotter recorded 0.75 inches of rain in 30 minutes near the intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding across central and southern Yavapai County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on State Highway 169 near Yarber Wash and a section of the highway was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning stuck and killed a man from the town of Nazlini.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 21-year-old man from the town of Nazlini was watching a rain swollen waterfall from a metal bridge. He was struck by a lightning bolt while standing on the bridge. He was transported to a Phoenix hospital where he later died.  Other individuals in the vicinity of the strike were knocked over by the shock wave but were not seriously injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a rock slide southeast of Bagdad.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from a thunderstorm caused a rock slide that closed State Route 95 at Mile Post 4 southeast of Bagdad.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in St Johns.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flooding in one home flooded and  threatened another home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and heavy rainfall across much of  NE Colorado, NW Kansas and SW Nebraska.  Hail up to tennis ball size cracked the windshield of a NWS co-op observer's car in Kit Carson county.

Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and heavy rainfall across much of  NE Colorado, NW Kansas and SW Nebraska.  Hail up to tennis ball size cracked the windshield of a NWS co-op observer's car in Kit Carson county.

Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and heavy rainfall across much of  NE Colorado, NW Kansas and SW Nebraska.  Hail up to tennis ball size cracked the windshield of a NWS co-op observer's car in Kit Carson county.
Hail and damaging thunderstorm winds moved across central Indiana throughout the day of August 16, 2007.  Heavy rain also accompanied the severe storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were down across U.S. 31 near Retreat due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail and damaging thunderstorm winds moved across central Indiana throughout the day of August 16, 2007.  Heavy rain also accompanied the severe storms.
Hail and damaging thunderstorm winds moved across central Indiana throughout the day of August 16, 2007.  Heavy rain also accompanied the severe storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain estimated at 2.25 inches fell causing some street flooding in Vincennes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front was the trigger for thunderstorms on the 2nd of June. The airmass was unstable out ahead of the front. The atmopheric column contained a moderate amount of wind shear which acted to organize the thunderstorms and enhance their severity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down in Goffstown. Penny size hail was reported in Bedford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front was the trigger for thunderstorms on the 2nd of June. The airmass was unstable out ahead of the front. The atmopheric column contained a moderate amount of wind shear which acted to organize the thunderstorms and enhance their severity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down on several roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front was the trigger for thunderstorms on the 2nd of June. The airmass was unstable out ahead of the front. The atmopheric column contained a moderate amount of wind shear which acted to organize the thunderstorms and enhance their severity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires down in Amesbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front was the trigger for thunderstorms on the 2nd of June. The airmass was unstable out ahead of the front. The atmopheric column contained a moderate amount of wind shear which acted to organize the thunderstorms and enhance their severity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Microburst occurred in Georgetown at approximately 7:10 pm EDT in Georgetown. Numerous trees and wires were downed. Winds estimated near 80 mph just southeast of the Crane Pond Wildlife Management Area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary was oriented west to east across central Ohio. The surface frontal boundary, in combination with upper level atmospheric support, allowed for severe thunderstorms to develop across the region. Many of the thunderstorms that day were severe, and even a few tornadoes developed across northern Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was observed just south of Benton Ridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary was oriented west to east across central Ohio. The surface frontal boundary, in combination with upper level atmospheric support, allowed for severe thunderstorms to develop across the region. Many of the thunderstorms that day were severe, and even a few tornadoes developed across northern Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and large limbs were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and mid-level disturbance moved into a hot and unstable airmass, with temperatures in the 90s and dewpoints in the mid to upper 60s, across Vermont during the afternoon of the 3rd. This resulted in scattered thunderstorms, some of which produced large hail. Large hail reports included; Golf ball size (1.75 inches diameter) in Richford, Half-dollar size (1.25 inches diameter) in Richford (Franklin county), Quarter size (1.00 inch diameter) in Highgate Springs (Franklin county)...North Troy and Orleans (Orleans county), with Nickel size in North Troy and Orleans.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail reported by spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and mid-level disturbance moved into a hot and unstable airmass, with temperatures in the 90s and dewpoints in the mid to upper 60s, across Vermont during the afternoon of the 3rd. This resulted in scattered thunderstorms, some of which produced large hail. Large hail reports included; Golf ball size (1.75 inches diameter) in Richford, Half-dollar size (1.25 inches diameter) in Richford (Franklin county), Quarter size (1.00 inch diameter) in Highgate Springs (Franklin county)...North Troy and Orleans (Orleans county), with Nickel size in North Troy and Orleans.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail reported at general store in Highgate Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through a warm and unstable airmass across Essex county New York during the afternoon of the 30th. Scattered thunderstorms developed across the region with some storms that produced large hail as well as damaging winds. Baseball sized hail was reported in Paradox as well as damaging winds that knocked down several trees. Golf ball sized hail was reported in Moriah with quarter size hail reported in Port Henry.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baseball sized hail was reported in the town of Paradox as well as several downed trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms containing damaging thunderstorm winds and heavy rain moved through central Indiana on the evening of August 24, 2007.  In addition, lightning struck Noblesville High School.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in Staunton due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into Southern New England was accompanied by an unstable airmass with relatively cold temperatures aloft for June. This allowed for several hail-producing thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees downed - one of which took down a telephone pole.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees downed in Manchester and Broad Brook. One tree crushed a car in Broad Brook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level low pressure system located just to the North of New England aided in the development of strong to locally severe thunderstorms on the 11th. The main result was hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through a warm and unstable airmass across Essex county New York during the afternoon of the 30th. Scattered thunderstorms developed across the region with some storms that produced large hail as well as damaging winds. Baseball sized hail was reported in Paradox as well as damaging winds that knocked down several trees. Golf ball sized hail was reported in Moriah with quarter size hail reported in Port Henry.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees reported blown down by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through a warm and unstable airmass across southern and eastern Vermont during the afternoon of the 30th. A few widely scattered thunderstorms moved across the region with some isolated reports of large hail. Nickel size hail was reported in Wells River (Orange county) with quarter size hail reported in Benson (Rutland county).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through a warm and unstable airmass across southern and eastern Vermont during the afternoon of the 30th. A few widely scattered thunderstorms moved across the region with some isolated reports of large hail. Nickel size hail was reported in Wells River (Orange county) with quarter size hail reported in Benson (Rutland county).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced a wind gust to 68 mph at Bark River in the early morning hours of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 68 mph reported by an observer at Bark River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Menominee and Delta counties on the afternoon of the 5th.
Severe thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Menominee and Delta counties on the afternoon of the 5th.
Severe thunderstorms pounded west and central Upper Michigan with large hail and damaging wind on the morning of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees stripped of leaves with some vehicle damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms pounded west and central Upper Michigan with large hail and damaging wind on the morning of the 8th.

Very hot and humid conditions prevailed across Southern New England on the 28th of June. This in combination with an approaching cold front aided in the development of thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Several of the storms became severe due to the rather strong instability in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Microburst occurred on the Stone-E-Lea Golf Course in Attleboro. Approximately 50 trees were downed on the course.

This in combination with an approaching cold front aided in the development of thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Several of the storms became severe due to the rather strong instability in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires downed in Rehoboth and Seekonk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid conditions prevailed across Southern New England on the 28th of June. This in combination with an approaching cold front aided in the development of thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Several of the storms became severe due to the rather strong instability in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires down in both Milton and Weymouth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid conditions prevailed across Southern New England on the 28th of June. This in combination with an approaching cold front aided in the development of thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Many of the storms produced wind damage and hail across Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large and powerful thunderstorm produced nickel to quarter size hail across a large area of Northern Rhode Island, including the cities of Woonsocket, Lincoln, and Smithfield.
